issues.description: Attribute type for 'lectureName' is inconsistent across artifacts. The problem statement UML and task text specify lectureName as a String, and the template expects students to add attributes accordingly. The solution repository introduces a separate LectureName class and declares the lectureName field as type LectureName. This deviates from the exercise specification and will confuse students about the intended type to implement.
issues.suggested_fix: Align the type of lectureName across all artifacts. Either: (a) revert the solution to use a String field for lectureName (matching the UML and template), or (b) update the problem statement and template to explicitly introduce and use the LectureName class (and adjust the UML and task text to indicate the custom type). Prefer (a) if the exercise intends to teach basic attributes/getters/setters with standard types.

issues.description: Constructor parameter types conflict with the specification. The problem statement requires a constructor that initializes attributes in the order shown in the UML (lectureName as a String, then four ints). The solution's constructor takes a LectureName object as the first parameter instead of a String, producing a mismatch with the specification and the expected signature students will implement.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the constructor signature consistent with the exercise specification. Either change the solution constructor to accept a String as the first parameter (Lecture(String lectureName, int ...)) or update the problem statement/template to document that LectureName is a custom type and should be used in the constructor.

issues.description: Getter return-type mismatch in the solution: getLectureName() is declared to return String but returns the lectureName field which is of type LectureName. This is an internal type/signature inconsistency in the solution implementation and will cause a compilation/type error.
issues.suggested_fix: Fix the getter to be type-consistent. Options: (a) change the field to String so that getLectureName(): String returns the field; (b) change the getter signature to return LectureName (public LectureName getLectureName()) if LectureName is intended; or (c) keep getter returning String but return lectureName.getValue() / lectureName.toString() (and ensure null-safety). Pick one approach and apply it consistently across constructor, setter and documentation.

issues.description: Setter parameter-type / assignment mismatch in the solution: setLectureName(String) accepts a String but assigns it directly to the lectureName field of type LectureName. This is an internal mismatch that will not compile and conflicts with the intended/simple setter behavior described in the task (which expects a String-based setter).
issues.suggested_fix: Make the setter signature and body consistent with the chosen lectureName representation. Options: (a) change setLectureName to accept LectureName and assign directly; (b) keep setLectureName(String) but inside assign this.lectureName = new LectureName(lectureName); (c) change the lectureName field to String and assign directly. Ensure documentation/constructor/getter are updated accordingly.

issues.description: The problem statement and UML specify the lectureName attribute as type String (lectureName: String), but the solution repository introduces a new LectureName class and changes the lectureName field to type LectureName. This creates a mismatch between the expected type in the exercise description and the solution implementation. Students reading the problem will expect to work with a String lectureName (and the template likely intends a String), while the solution uses a different type and an extra class (LectureName). This divergence can cause confusion about the intended representation of the lecture name and whether students should implement or use a custom LectureName type or a plain String.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the representation of lectureName consistent across artifacts. Either (a) revert the solution to use a plain String for lectureName (change the field, constructor parameter, getter and setter to String and remove the LectureName class), which aligns with the UML and expected student implementation; or (b) update the problem statement and template to document and use the LectureName type explicitly (change UML to lectureName: LectureName and explain the purpose of the LectureName class). Prefer option (a) unless the custom type is an intentional pedagogical goal.
